video.title: How to Become a Developer
video.description:
Learn about how to become a developer and how to be an outstanding junior developer. And here's an update 2.5 years later from John: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lo4BSraYvc8 

Talk by John Mosesman at the freeCodeCamp OKC meetup. Thanks to John and Techlahoma for giving us permission to share.

https://johnmosesman.com/
https://twitter.com/johnmosesman

Follow Techlahoma's YouTube channel at: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCnLf0pfqIpSfKuPZ0e9iiNQ

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://medium.freecodecamp.org

topLevelComment.author: John Mosesman
topLevelComment.text:
Hey everyone! Thanks for watching and leaving the comments and questions here. I've read them all, and I re-watched the talk again now 2.5 years later. 

You all left some great questions around things in the talk I didn't cover or could have explained better, so I made a video discussing all of those things in greater detail: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5azUw1Asp20

- John

replies.author: John Mosesman
replies.text:
​@jedimasterham2 Hey! By non-computer science do you mean non-technical skills like management or planning or do you mean programming-related but not the math/theory of computer science?

For your second question I'm not sure I'm the right person to ask haha but my initial thought was I think we're just scratching the surface of AI/machine learning, and over time most software things will have some kind of AI/ML component.

I'm interested in and investigating the web3 space as well, so that could be interesting over that timeframe too!

replies.author: jedimasterham2
replies.text:
Hi John, I'm just starting out with freeCodeCamp. What other non-computer science training do you think would positively supplement a career in development? 

And what fields within computer science do you see growing significantly in the next 5-10 years?

replies.author: John Mosesman
replies.text:
​@Jeremy Thornton I mentioned this in my followup video but I used poor phrasing here :/

I meant that websites have involved into interactive web applications, not just a page of static files with links pointing to new pages (like the SpaceJam website I mention).

This is still poor phrasing because static sites are obviously big in the blog/site world.

The TL;DR I meant was that you should aim to build interactive apps using a web framework, not just HTML/CSS (although those are important too).

topLevelComment.author: Bersi
topLevelComment.text:
This is one of the most honest video I've watched about programming careers.
1. Tool - Choose and learn a language.
2. Experience - Build a CRUD app (create, read, update, destroy).
3. Update yourself - Learn other tech things not necessarily related to your tools, to start building a full idea of what you are doing.
4. Go to step 1.

Extras:
5. Build an online present (be present as developer on eg. Twitter).
6. Find and build your network (partcipate to Open Source Projects, get in touch in forums, ...).
7. Experiment as much as you can, to grow even more your experience.

Advice:
"The only wrong choice, is to not make a choice at all."
"Ask the Duck!"
"Print it out."

topLevelComment.author: Nastaran Kian Ersi
topLevelComment.text: I've been a software developer for a year and a half now. I watched this lecture to see where I really am on this path. It was a great lecture, thank you so much. I really struggled learning programming but after trying and trying and trying again, I finally made it. And that imposter syndrome, I live with it everyday :D

replies.author: Nastaran Kian Ersi
replies.text: @Duncan Doge Excellent! We might always figure out our actual interest on the learning path, no matter how much we think the path in perfect at the start. Looking forward to seeing you where you want to be!

replies.author: Duncan Doge
replies.text:
@Nastaran Kian Ersi thanks for your time!
Yeah I'm guilty of jumping between courses and not finishing one.
I started with The Odin Project, halfway throug it i moved to a  JavaScript course on Udemy, I liked JavaScript but felt i was learning rules by memory, so i switched to CS50 and is a lot more suited to me to let me understand the underlying logic that links together every aspect of CS.
Yes maybe finishing those courses and then starting CS50 would have still got me a bit ahead in some parts of the course.
But i felt like only Web development was not too fit for me, had i had to rely only on it to look for jobs I think wouldn't have landed me any good jobs here.
Now with a bit of understanding of python and SQL I have a broader perspective and know-how to move around concepts a bit easier.
I absolutely have to get on this harder, I'm wasting a lot of time on small progresses
Thanks a lot!

replies.author: Nastaran Kian Ersi
replies.text:
@Duncan Doge My experience: 1)I think the language you start with doesn't matter that much. There are tons of languages with their own pros and cons and use cases. Programming is mostly about problem solving. If you're at month one (probably month two, by now), you've already picked you language. If you like it, I suggest you stick to it.
2) You can learn through self-study, and you can learn by taking classes and boot-camps. If you can afford it, I suggest you pick the latter. But if you pick the former, you need to be consistent, practice, solve problems and do mini-projects while you're learning.
3) I started with c++, I've been using c++ and Qt to make desktop applications. I loved it. c++ can give you a lot of insight into programming concepts in general.
Good luck, and I hope my comment won't get deleted this time :D

replies.author: Nastaran Kian Ersi
replies.text:
@med ben Smart?? Come on, don't even use that word. Everybody is smart and everybody can do what they like if they put effort to it. Different people might need different amounts of time to learn something and that's no problem at all. 
About English, I know some people who are at pre-intermediate level but are great developers. However, it will make it easier to know English and be comfortable with it. If it's your passion, just start ;)

topLevelComment.author: ryan derksen
topLevelComment.text: I have been trying to learn programming for a number of years now . I am curious to know what the most productive things that I can do to learn python . I am not exactly a beginner I know a good amount of stuff however putting it together makes little sense to me , I am also having a tough time with indenting , strings and using alternate libraries . I have some books teaching me exactly how to right particular programs . There are a few problems with that I am not sure exactly what is in that library however I guess I could probably just go into that library and see what is in it . One of the books that I have teaches pygame zero and another book teaches tkinter and yet another book teaches the main library  . My learning disability makes learning programming way difficult and with no real support group I am on my own as far as learning goes . I have talked to people about programming before and they are usually nice about sharing information but it is usually incomplete information or they do not want to talk about it at all or their attitude is that they are not going to hold your hand through the whole learning process but things like this take hard work so I am just going to put it more effort . could you explain to me the difference between programming and object oriented programming . If I am correct any app that you write is going to use object oriented programming and I guess business is done in regular programming and if that is the case why would you write it in computer code and not just write it down ? I am guessing the answer to that would be encryption .

replies.author: ryan derksen
replies.text: @E. E G  I  would love to help . I am having a bunch of trouble . I have been at it for about four years . What I am finding through experience is that after you have learned the basics is that you have to learn to code on your feet . What I mean by that is that you have to write programs using what you know and pickup little bits of information  . Even if you have no clue what the program does at least you made something.. Once you have written something save it , open up a new file and write something different  . I suggest coding books that have pre written programs chances are you will learn some new syntax . Idk if YouTube videos are the way to go because even if you can see it and understand ,it they often go to fast forget to explain something or expect you to copy the code without any explanation.. Plus at that point you are not learning you are copying code aka learning how to steal someone elses work .

I really don't know how to use Github or much technological stuff but...soon. 
Good luck man 👍

replies.author: mage
replies.text: @uwu .-. yeah, I wish so much that I could put if statements or other logical parameters into search bars sometimes. And yeah, I understand that "SITE:YouTube .com," "-car," and "dress OR pants" are logical parameters, but the syntax is very limited. What I would really like is a whole C-like language I could use in the search bar to refine and combine searches. Maybe implement it the same way C implements Assembly inline: __asm("code goes here", "each line has its own quote block"); Well, not exactly like that maybe, but similar would be nice. The logical syntax in C and other programing languages is very frangible and quite powerful.

replies.author: uwu .-.

replies.author: mage
replies.text: @Oncopoda YouTube comments history. Build an app to procedurally load every historical comment in order from most recent to least recent, and perform a "Ctrl+F" on each one individually. Then, if you've posted a lot of "I'll update in (x) years" comments, also filter the comments through this case "if (xYears > commentAge) TRUE;" and output every comment that's true. Repeat ad nauseum with additional search parameters until you have a useful number of comments to look through, as in less than 20-50.

replies.author: random bit
replies.text:
@A. ah you fell pray to the sunk cost fallacy and now you're just trying to make yourself feel like it was worth it.

Sad reality is 99% of what you learned in school goes completely unused. Your job/interviews will literally just be about extremely specific topics about the role and your work culture. If you think you need a degree to pass DS/A interview questions idk what to tell you about all the non-CS hires at companies. There's evidence to disprove your entire premise.

replies.author: A.

Sincerely a BSc in Computer Engineering

topLevelComment.author: delubio lopes de Paula
topLevelComment.text: Math is a SUBSTANTIAL skill to become a great programmer. If you're not good in Math you're going to struggle a lot. A person who deals with numbers fairly easy, will fly through programming otherwise it going to be painful. You can learn, you can do it, but ........

replies.author: DarknessVoid
replies.text: Dammit I ain't talented at maths their goes my dreams of being a programmer mainly cause Im dyslexic

replies.author: delubio lopes de Paula
replies.text:
@One Time Go slow, take classes on Khan Academy it's free and it's really cool tool to sharp your math skills. If you take really serious you could reinvigorate your math in 8 to 10 months.
Then you you move to the next step which is learning a computer language. I suggest you Python. Python is in high demand and it's not really hard to learn.
Another hint, don't fall into the trap of trying to learn 3 or 4 languages at once. Doesn't work and will get you really frustrated.
One more hint, don't go for the libraries like React, Vue. Learn Python, learn well and only after that you can start to spread your wings towards other languages an libraries.
Good luck to you, eventually you're going to master all this and find your dream job.

topLevelComment.author: Robby Price
topLevelComment.text:
I appreciate the upload. I have to say I disagree that you don't need to be smart. Projects have deadlines, if you aren't smart you take longer. Time is money and developers aren't cheap. 

I had two junior dev jobs. I was smoking weed like my last name was Marley. Both jobs fired me for the same reason. I took too long. What I did produce was great work but I was running at half speed. 

I stopped smoking and now my memory ram is loading my old teachings fast and I can keep track of way more in my head at once.

I have a 127 IQ, scored perfect scores on my SAT and ACT earning Scholar's Awards, etc. My uncle has a 137 IQ and he is WAY smarter than me. He worked at Apple in Cupertino for 20 years before he retired on his 40th birthday. My cousin graduated Stanford University with a Ph.D in Physics and now works at Netflix doing Algorithm development, my best friend from HS works for Google on the cloud team. My uncle on my moms side works at Autodesk and is self taught. Each of them are incredibly smart people. And they have 0 patience for people who slow them down. They wrecked my confidence dozens of times, but I'm sober as a bird now and looking to make this happen on my own.
